reference.title: DITA 1.3 proposed feature #13107

ul.li: Date that this feature proposal was completed: 2013-03-01
Champion of the proposal: Chris Nitchie

section.title: Original requirement or use case
section.p: The processor default values for @scope, @format, and @type make sense for local DITA topic references. However, for some common links, especially those to external HTTP URLs, the processor defaults can cause problems in some processors, resulting in a need to set those attributes explicitly. The default values should be informed by value of the @href attribute.

section.title: Use cases
section.p: An author creates a link to a web URL using simply an @href, but without any value for @scope, @format, or @type. When that link is published, it is effectively treated as an external HTML link, and the content is not copied to the output location.

section.title: Proposed solution
section.p: When determining the effective value for @scope, @format, and @type:

ol.li: If the attribute is explicitly specified, that value is used.
If the attribute exists on an ancestor element such that its value will cascade into this element, that value is used.
Otherwise, the effective default is determined by examining the value of the @href attribute.

section.p: The rules for specific attributes would be as follows.

dlentry.dd: If the @href attribute specifies an absolute URI whose scheme is http: or https:, then the effective value is "external". Otherwise, the effective value is "local". If the @href attribute specifies a relative URI, then scope is always "local" regardless of what the resolved absolute URI would be. For example, if a map is stored on a WebDAV server at "http://example.com/docs/myMap.ditamap", and it contains <topicref href="topics/topic1.dita"/>, then the scope of that topicref is "local" even though the resolved absolute URI of the referenced topic has a scheme of "http".

ul.li: Generally, if the @href attribute specifies a file extension, the effective @format will be that extension, after conversion to lower-case, and with no leading period.
The only exception to this is if the extension is "xml", in which case the effective @format will be "dita".
If there is no extension, but the @href value is an absolute URI whose scheme is http: or https:, then the effective value is "html".

Processors may, but need not, provide a mechanism by which other URI patterns can be mapped to effective @format values. This could cause interoperability problems without a standard way of providing custom mappings, and as such, I'm not married to this provision. However, whether we say it or not, vendors are liable to do it.

dlentry.dd: If the effective @format is "dita" and there is no fragment identifier, or the fragment identifier does not contain '/', then the effective value is "topic". Otherwise, there is no effective default value. In such cases, if the effective @scope is "local", processors should determine the effective value by examining the link target, per the current rules.

section.title: Benefits
section.p: This will simplify the requirements on link authors to specify correct values for the linking attributes that go along with @href, leading to simpler authoring.

dlentry.dd: Some processors may have to update their link handling code according to the rules outlined above.
This will simplify the link authoring process for DITA authors.

section.title: Costs
section.p: The specification topics covering the @scope, @format, and @type attributes will need to be updated to reflect the new processor defaults. Also, the above rules should be collected in some single topic, probably the topic, URI-based (direct) addressing, or to a new topic somewhere in the language specification.

Authoring tools may need to update the logic that determines whether linking attributes need to be explicitly specified when inserting links. However, there will be no harm if authoring tools continue to insert explicit attributes that match these new processor defaults. When a link is activated in an authoring tool without explicit values, that logic will also need to be updated to determine the appropriate behavior when activating the link.

These rules may lead to greater percieved complexity. However, it will actually make the authoring of non-local, non-dita links considrably simpler. In the vast majority of cases, only an @href will be required, and the other attributes will take care of themselves.
